newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean prosecutors probe parliamentary speaker.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean prosecutors probe parliamentary speaker.

text.p: South Korean prosecutors began questioning parliamentary speaker Kim Soo-han on Saturday over allegations he took money from the founder of the troubled Hanbo Group.

Television broadcasts showed two state prosecutors entering the speaker's official residence for the questioning. It is the first time that a head of South Korea's legislature has been probed by prosecutors
Earlier this week state prosecutors said Hanbo founder Chung Tae-soo had told them that he had donated funds to help Kim's parliamentary election campaign in 1992.
The prosecution has said it will announce the outcome of the probe on Kim soon.
Kim was among 33 politicians named by Chung or his aides as having taken money from Hanbo as "political funds". Chung, now in jail on corruption charges, has denied bribing them.

Chung is on trial along with nine others, including three close associates of President Kim Young-sam, in connection with the January collapse of Hanbo Steel Co, flagship of the country's 14th largest conglomerate.
